titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck, September 1, 1906
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
titleStmt.sponsor: Supported in part by a grant from the Wyoming Cultural Trust Fund, a program of the Department of State Parks and Cultural Resources.

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck

msIdentifier.repository: University of Wyoming, American Heritage Center, Buffalo Bill: Letters to George T. Beck, 1895-1910 (Acc. #9972)

div1.p: If nothing happens to prevent I will leave Wapiti2 Oct 15th for a ten days hunt. I propose going up Elk fork get up on the Wapiti Ridge4 and hunting the heads of Hard Pan3. Bob Cat on the south heds of Fish hawk3. Eagle3 and up wapiti ridge to head of Ishawooa5 & down to TE6. I will have but three or four particular friends with me. And I want you to be one of them I will send a Pack outfit to meet us at Wapiti starting from there Oct 15th I hope to arrive in Cody Oct 10th

postscript.p: PS. I hope the Citizens of Cody are urgeing the building of the high line Canal which I have written about before
Germany is doing fine about $50000 a week-

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Metz, Germany, September 1-2, 1906.
Note 2: Wapiti is located twenty miles west of Cody, Wyoming, on the North Fork of the Shoshone River.
Note 3: Elk Fork, Hard Pan, Bobcat, Fish Hawk, and Eagle are tributary creeks that feed the north and south forks of the Shoshone River west of Cody, Wyoming.
Note 4: Wapiti Ridge lies between the north and south forks of the Shoshone River, west of Cody, Wyoming.
Note 5: Ishawooa Creek is located on the South Fork of the Shoshone River.
Note 6: TE Ranch, located on the South Fork of the Shoshone River, was owned by William F. Cody.
